comments.content:
Documentation
The job isn’t complete until the paperwork is complete. In this case, the following should be
updated to reflect the changed state of the network:
■■ Network configurations
■■ Additions to network
■■ Physical location changes

discussion.content: change management should be contacted and approval is required before any change is made. So all parties affected by the change must sign off on the change. So change management is totally aware of this new router. Change management records these changes so should a change go bad or bring instability to the network they can roll back to the previous settings. The next thing needing updating is the network diagram as a new physical router has been added.

comments.content: I saw the same question and the same question popped in my head. Now this is saying change management which is really weird.

discussion.content: There was a very similar question on here and the answer was logical network diagram, so I;m kinda confused...

"which of the following needs to be done to record the change the technician is making to the company network?" May be a question problem, but reading this sounds like the tech has not made the change yet and it's asking what he needs to do before "making" the change. In which is, Change Management.

Official CompTIA statement (online learning):
When the change has been implemented, its impact should be assessed, and the process reviewed and documented to identify any outcomes that could help future change management projects.
So, the correct answer should be A
"Once the task is complete" you need to finish the change management document and say that the task was done.

questions.question_text: A network technician receives reports indicating some users are unable to gain access to any network resources. During troubleshooting, the technician discovers the workstations have an IP address of 169.254.x.x. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

An employee, who is using a laptop connected to the wireless network, is able to connect to the Internet but not to internal company resources. A systems administrator reviews the following information from the laptop:

IP: 192.168.1.100 -

MASK: 255.255.255.0 -

ROUTER: 192.168.1.1 -
The administrator was expecting to see a network address within 10.100.0.0/23, which is consistent with the company's wireless network. The network administrator verifies the company's wireless network is configured and working properly. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this issue?

discussion.content: The employee is connected to a different network since their IP address is not in the range of the company’s addressing scheme. So, wrong SSID/network will be the answer here.

comments.content: I agree with you. When i revealed the answer i was shocked. I second it should be Asset Tag.

discussion.content: Why wouldn't this be A, "Asset tracking tags?" How would a computer lock help you recover the device? Locks would be the BEST asset in preventing the desktops from going missing at the start. But in this scenario,the desktops are already missing or lost, the locks won't do anything for recovery. However, asset tracking tags (if they had been applied) could aid in the identification and recovery. If I'm mistaken, please let me know.

The question would be, would a asset tracking tags help in recovering a missing device? They can be wireless-enabled transmitters, but how effective are they when recovering a missing device? When I see a question asking for the "BEST" option, I assume the correct answer isn't always going to be straight forward. D might the correct answer. Whos knows....next question
The correct answer should be A, asset tags can be tracked and also they can be designed to make a noise at the door if they are RFID.
Locks don't help you "recover" devices.

just as the rest of you are suggesting it, the answer should be A. Asset "TRACKING" tags are the only thing here that would help you RECOVER those devices. The other three options are only for PREVENTION. Asset Tracking tags can be active (battery powered) or passive, requiring a reader up close to the tag. Even completely dumb "asset tags" which are nothing more than a sticker declaring who it belongs to are better than nothing, because the equipment might turn up somewhere and the finder could return the equipment to the owner.
No way. I disagree. The term "assist recovering" makes it A
Has to be A......

A company finds that many desktops are being reported as missing or lost. Which of the following would BEST assist in recovering these devices?

My second language is English but this test is not only about networking but also reading comprehension. A is the answer because of the word RECOVERING

Keep in mind, exam dumps are mostly created by test takers' "memory". So the questions are most likely not exact, nor is the answer always correct. Use them for what they are, do not memorize answers, verify and research what you don't know and you'll do great on the exam!
For me the answer is A, locks are for prevention, not recovery
I agree w everyone here, i believe answer is A, computer locks definitely don't have GPS, they are used as a prevention mechanism not a RECOVERY mechanism!

questions.question_text: A company finds that many desktops are being reported as missing or lost. Which of the following would BEST assist in recovering these devices?

A network topology requires a switch to be placed in an unsecured location. Which of the following techniques should be used to prevent unauthorized access?
(Choose two.)

discussion.content: remember - it's what comptia wants you to answer, think from their perspective.

When configuring security for wireless networks, filtering by MAC address is
a common practice. Typically, in MAC filtering security, MAC addresses can
be added to an “allow” ACL or “deny” ACL.

Another name for a network card or network adapter is a network controller.
Every controller has a unique MAC address associated with it. Filtering network
traffic using a system’s MAC address typically is done using an ACL. This list
keeps track of all MAC addresses and is configured to allow or deny access to
certain systems based on the list.
